< Back NRAO Very Large Array
Welcome to the National Radio Astronomy Observatory's Very Large Array in New Mexico!
The drive to the VLA is quintessential southwestern American desert. Not much to look at, but it's beautiful.
The "radio sundial", with pillars for hours and many periodic celestial events represented on the ground plaques.
Plaques commemorating the installation of the radio sundial itself, as well as the dates of some important scientific discoveries (and discoverers). Many more are spread out on the 600 square foot instrument.
The radio sundial's Gnomon.
The closest dish for visitor viewing, fully functional.
One of the three arms of dishes, stretching about 7 miles away behind the rail tracks that move them around.
The dishes fixed onto another target in the sky; they changed probably 5 times while we were there.
Ludicrous with Bessie in tow, checking out the views.
The repair bay and one of the locomotives specially built to transport the dishes around the valley. At each track intersection, the rig can make a 90° turn by jacking up on hydraulic pumps, rotating each of its four sets of wheels, and setting back down ready to move in the new direction.
